review_title: Honestly, Best Sandbox VR Game There Is
one_reviews_text:
I will be honest, I'm a stickler for graphics within VideoGames nowadays - if it isnt smooth, I won't bother buying it. This game however, shocked me. Utterly shocked me. In the beginning I had my doubts, but BoneWorks proved me wrong, in not only the graphical design and storytelling fashion, but everything else! From the smooth and realistic physics engine that makes you feel like the experience is one of your own, to the insanely fitting and overall genius score (credit to the sound wizard that is Michael Wyckoff). This game has truly revolutionised what Virtual Reality should feel like, sound like, be like. Stress Level Zero are un-friggin-believable for what they have done for VR Gaming fans and especially the VR Market, they have essentially set the bar so high for future VR Games/Experiences, that we cannot help but expect out that same level of 'wow factor' out of the big, rich games companies from now on after seeing what a relatively smallish team (in comparison) of dedicated programmers who truly appreciate the craft can accomplish. Hence my undecided vote of this being the best game on the VR Market.

(P.S I highly recommend installing mods for sandbox and the story as soon as you finish the game, it totally revives the experience and keeps on giving. I will link first a youtube tutorial on how to do so and secondly the website that will provide the mods

Tutorial (Downloadable Content) - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6mOhVxKEiZM 
Thunderstore (Mod site) - https://boneworks.thunderstore.io/ )
Hope this helped, sorry it was long-winded :)

review_title: Fantastic VR Game For Any VR User
one_reviews_text:
Before I had a Rift S I wanted this game so bad. Now that I got one this was the 2nd game I bought. 
       
       Right out of the box, this game is great. You begin to learn how to interact with the world and objects and learn the physics before the main part of the story begins. The physics are incredible. Period. Interaction with the world is fun and you need to be very involved with it. If you are a new user to VR it may be difficult to grasp how to interact with the world. But with practice and gameplay it becomes much easier. 
       The audio and music is excellent and it changes based upon where you are in the game (if you want to listen to the music look up "Bonetones" online). 
       You need to solve lots of puzzles and difficult tasks in this game. It gave me the same feeling when playing Portal 2, having to think heavily and really stretch my brain to find a solution. Sometimes it's best to take a short break and clear your mind if it feels overwhelming.
        This game performed really well on my computer (GTX 1060 3gb, i5 4590). I worried I would be unable to run the game, but it ran beautifully. I set shadows to low, 2x MSAA, half textures, and disabled Ambient Oclusion. 
        In terms of motion sickness, I did not feel sick during gameplay. If you have a not good PC the game could lag and make you feel nausous. But in my case I felt fine playing.

review_title: A Mixed Bag of a Game
one_reviews_text:
TLDR: this game is a mixed bag. I played through the entire thing, just to say that I played what amounts to a technical marvel with no personality to it. If a player’s only goal is to finish a game, then the game itself isn’t fun. And what’s the point in playing something that’s not fun 

So. This game was a huge mixed bag, elements of it were fantastic while others fell flat on their face. To make it easier to write my thoughts, I’ll separate it into Highs and Lows. 

Highs: 
- Soundtrack: I’m a sucker for a good soundtrack and holy heck it sounds beautiful. Ethereal tracks for inside buildings and high-octane battle music. It always feels like something is trying to play in the background, which makes the quiet sections of the game even more painful to sit though. I just want to hear the pretty music, not deafening silence while I struggle with the puzzles. That was more of a low I know, I’ve got a couple nitpicks with everything. 
- Body Physics: I’ll give credit where credit is due, the body you have ingame is a technical marvel. It moves the same way your actual body would. It can jump decently, and move decently. All of the guns are weighted to THAT body. Another nitpick here- but while the body was impressive, it didn’t feel good to control. I’m a women of fairly tall build, mainly long legs and arms, and I couldn’t for the life of me feel comfortable using the body. 

Lows: 
- Level Design: okay first off, why the color palette? Everything had the same gray and boring texture, making it virtually impossible to keep track of everything, and the game having a lot of back tracking makes it a hell of a job to move from place to place. 
- Puzzles: now, I know what your going to say . “Oh Mae, is the puzzles too hard for your stupid head to  comprehend?”. To that, I’d say your pretty much correct, but I’d add to that saying the extra things in each puzzle makes them more difficult to solve. Now  to give context to this, there’s one part of the Runoffs section of the game where you have to somehow pull a dumpster into this pit to create a bridge to go to the other side. It’s a fairly small room, and the pit was somewhat close to where the dumpster was. Also in that room is a lever to open a huge garage style door, I saw the door and immediately pulled the dumpster outside and tried for about 20 minutes to pull it over to a ledge earlier in the level. This might have just me being stupid, but for the sake of us stupid people please don’t make your puzzles needlessly complicated. 
- Item Physics: I don’t know why, but everything except for weapons has horrible physics. Like for example, picking up a crate. For a game praised for its amazing physics, it’s a real pain to pick up something and have it spin around like crazy while it flaps into your body. It’s just so weird for a game like this to have problems with its physics. And  still on this topic, why do items like clipboard have to be held in the worst way possible? Is it just me or are they just hard to hold ? 
- Combat: Couple things and I’ll keep it brief, add an hp bar and some visual cues for when your out of ammo. I’d rather not have to guess whether or not my gun needs more ammo, waiting for that little outline of the clip to come suddenly. Also blunt weapons are a complete joke, with the physics the way they are you’re more likely to wake yourself with the mallet rather than a enemy. 
- WorldBuliding: this is also minor, but the monomats need some context. I’m pretty sure they weren’t in the museum, so when I came across one in the Streets I had no idea what it was or how to use it. Maybe to add to the worldbuliding, have a poster  on the side of it explaining how to use one. Nothing fancy but something like “It’s easy! Turning ammo into Money! The system of the future”. I didn’t figure out how they worked until super late into the game, probably another stupid Maeday moment but it still stands 

So in conclusion, this game is a mixed bag. I played through the entire thing, just to say that I played what amounts to a technical marvel with no personality to it. If a player’s only goal is to finish a game, then the game itself isn’t fun. And what’s the point in playing something that’s not fun

I was originally on the fence about buying this game, since the reviews are fairly mixed, and eventually I got it. I’ve played through most of the campaign, and I decided to write a review.

Pros

Weapons—it’s amazing what the devs did. Each one is as smooth as butter and works exactly like I want them to.

Locomotion—also pretty smooth, but also not for the faint of heart. I’m pretty experienced in VR, so I had no trouble using it. However, if you are prone to motion sickness or are new to VR, don’t buy this game. It’s not as bad as Rec Room, but can still make you sick.

Enemies—fun to fight, as each is different, though a suggestion would be to have the nullmen have weapons like guns or axes so they’re harder to fight.

Levels—fun to go through, and I like that it’s got alleyways and stuff and chests with new guns and ammo. 

Puzzles—fun, yet challenging. I like how you can solve them in different ways than the intended way even if you cheat or do something new.

Slow motion—actually a neat feature. It totally makes you feel like an action hero as you leap into the air, slow-mo, do a 360, all while shooting at enemies with the accuracy and precision of John Wick. I was skeptical of it when it was introduced, but it is awesome.

Cons

Story—they call it a “mysterious narrative”, but as you play it, it becomes more of a confusing narrative. No spoilers, but some of the actions your character does in the story confuses me, and contradicts what the main plot is about. It’d be nice if they actually gave Boneworks a solid story that’s easy to understand. Once I complete maybe I’ll understand it better.

Grabbing things—it’s kind of annoying how you have to use the grip button and the trigger to grab things, but you get used to it.

Enemies—they lack variety and they don’t get stronger. They don’t introduce new enemies into fights to make them tougher, they just throw more of the same in there.

That’s all I have.

I have been incredibly hyped for Boneworks for probably close to a year. Watching videos of gameplay over the months, mixed with the reception of Half Life Alyx, saw me recently build a new PC to invest in the next wave of VR games.

For the first evening (1-2 hours) honestly I didn't enjoy it much at all. It was giving me mild motion sickness and the big open levels had me doing a lot of running about. On top of that, the physics felt way clunkier than how they appeared in videos - it just wasn't the experience I was hoping for.

I plugged in again the next day and after another 1-2hrs the gameplay started to click. I grasped a better idea of how to move my body within the gameworld and became quicker at performing tasks. This improved my enjoyment dramatically as I became more creative with the environment. By the end of the game the controls felt second nature and I was able to run around without feeling ill - trying to throw as much style into my combat as possible.

I wasn't blown away by the story and I didn't feel particulary invested in the world. The pacing and level design felt off at times, with some puzzles more frustrating to complete physically than they were to actually solve. I think the game struggles with it's identity at times, drawing itself uncomfortably close to Half Life but without fully capturing the things that make that franchise great. Ultimately it's a comparison that doesn't flatter and possibly does more harm than good.

It's a shame too, because Boneworks has some great things to offer but it doesn't explore them enough. The physics here (once you get used to them) are absolutely the star of the show but they could have been used in more interesting ways. 

Overall I had a good time with Boneworks and I'll enjoy going in to do the arena/challenge modes some more.  It's an impressive physics showcase that unfortunately doesn't capitalise on it's best ideas. A definite game to try out and play with - just not the killer app I once hoped

review_title: Incredibly over-rated even for tech demo
one_reviews_text:
I've played ALL the major VR games released to date, and I went into this one with only moderate expectations despite the hype.  I was basically expecting a Blade and Sorcery-style physics sandbox, except with guns and a narrative/puzzle campaign.  Instead, this plays more like VR QWOP.  Everything about it is incredibly janky and clunky.  In something like QWOP or Surgeon Simulator the jankiness is intended and is supposed to be funny.  Here it is just frustrating and makes an already boring game even worse.  Nothing is explained properly, maybe to encourage you to explore on your own.  That would be fine, except exploring is, like everything else here, slow, boring, and clunky.  

I honestly tried to give this one a fair shot, but having spent  maybe 2 hours, I'm not sure I can bring myself to play anymore - it is just that tedious.  Maybe this game was meant to be played on the Index and isn't so terrible there.
